awd_titl_txt: MRI:  Acquisition of a Lumicks C-Trap microscope for the study of biomaterials at the nanoscale and education in the South East
awd_abstract_narration:
An award is made to Emory University to support the acquisition of a new advanced microscope that combines optical tweezers for high precision mechanical pulling and nm-resolution fluorescence detection for spectroscopic localization of single molecules in microfluidic cells that allow rapid and non-disruptive exchange of experimental conditions.  At Emory, the acquisition of this microscope will enhance and extend existing, and enable new, projects spanning from genome transcription and maintenance to the mechano-biochemistry of muscle protein function, shear sensing in blood, the design of molecular tension sensors and motors and materials nano-physics.   The system will directly impact research and training infrastructure, the quality of undergraduate and graduate education and, ultimately, STEM education.  The microscope will be part of the Core Research Facilities shared among the research Universities in the Atlanta area through the Georgia Research Alliance.

The research projects enabled by the acquisition of this system will allow i) the understanding of key processes at the level of the genome such as the effect of elongating RNA polymerase on regulatory proteins normally bound to DNA (and vice versa) and the repair and editing of the genome; ii) understanding of the mechanism of force sensing in living muscle and blood cells; iii) the design of molecular force sensors, probes and motors for biotechnological applications; and iv) extension of the length scale over which advanced fluorescent detection techniques are applicable. The spectrum of research areas that will be transformed by these investigations is broad, connects fundamental with applied research and the natural synergies among the users which will lead to a stronger and better integrated research environment at Emory.  Results from these studies will be published in peer-reviewed journals and presented at scientific meetings.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Salaita group (Emory Chemistry) and The Ke group (Emory BioEngineering) independently used the Lumicks optical trapping system (C-Trap) to calibrate molecular tension sensors/probes that were synthesized in the group. One major class of tension probes consists in a DNA hairpin flanked by a fluorophore-quencher pair. Upon the application of an external pN force, these hairpins unfold, which leads to an increase in the fluorescence signal. Figure 1 A shows the general experimental approach to calibrate these DNA hairpin structures using the C-Trap. We developed molecular biology methods to ligate the DNA hairpins to micron-sized DNA handles. Preliminary data shown below confirms a successful force-ramp where the unfolding of the DNA hairpin was characterized as a minor inflection in the force-extension curve (Figure 1B). A second type of probe that is being calibrated using the C-Trap is comprised of a coiled-coil domain (antiparallel geometry). The group is working to calibrate this probe by linking recombinantly expressed peptides with DNA handles (See Figure 2). Preliminary data confirming the force-induced denaturation of DNA hairpins was obtained and was consistent with published literature. A US patent was filed for the shear force nanoreporter by the Ke lab and an application for a NIH "Center on Probes for Molecular Mechanotechnology."

The Li group (Emory Pediatrics) developed a procedure to conjugate long 5-kb DNA handles to both ends of the AIM-A1 fragment of the Van Willebrand Factor. A recombinant AIM-A1 protein that contains a SpyTag sequence on both of its N- and C-terminal ends was produced. Recombinant SpyCatcher protein with a free Cysteine residue was produced, and then conjugated to a meleimade-oligonucleotide. SpyTag-AIM-A1-SpyTag was then mixed with SpyCatcher-oligo to form an oligo-SpyCatcher-SpyTag-AIM-A1-SpyTag-SpyCatcher-oligo protein0-DNA chimera. The oligonucleotide sequence anneals to the 5-kb DNA handle that was attached to a streptavidin-bead that can be laser trapped in the C-Trap microscope. Initial test of this system suggested that an event consistent with AIM unfolding could be detected. Overall, this procedure shows some promise but requires further optimization.

The Schmidt group used the C-Trap to study the mechanical properties of suspended 3T3 fibroblasts cells. They trapped two dielectric (polystyrene) microspheres present in one of the flow channels of the microscope microfluidic cell (Bead Channel, Figure 3A), and then attached those to opposite sides of a cell in a laterally separated channel (Cell Channel). They transferred the suspended cells into the Medium Channel and manipulated the trap positions to impose deformations on the cells (Figure 3 A, B). Trap distance was periodically changed with a triangular wave form, and the forcers exerted on the cells and indentation amplitudes were recorded by the instrument (Figure 3C). Experimental data was analyzed using lumicks.pylak software and showed that cells respond the more rigidly the faster the imposed deformations are (Figure 3D). This result is consistent with a viscoelastic response of the suspended living cells. This resulted in a successful application for an NIHS10 grant to purchase their own C-Trap.

The Fernandez group (UTK ) utilized the C-Trap microscope to characterize conformational changes in DNA that are induced upon binding of the transcription factor, nuclear receptor thyroid hormone receptor-α (TRα). It is predicted that a second DNA-binding site exists on TRα which would induce a bending or looping of DNA. C-Trap data were obtained using a 1050bp DNA adduct chemically tethered (with digoxigenin and biotin, respectively) to two microbeads held in optical traps (Figure 4A). The resistance force needed to maintain the DNA in a completely extended conformation was recorded in Force (pN) versus Distance (nm) curves (F-D curves). By comparing F-D curves of DNA alone (blue lines) and complexed with full-length TRα (pink line) and truncated TRα (red line) we observe that full-length TRα (FLTRα) exerts significant strain on the extended DNA conformation (Figure 4B). This is indicated by the greater force at corresponding distances in the F-D curves (Figure 4B).

The Shekhar group (Emory Physics) investigates the mechanochemistry of actin filament bundling by Fascin. To this end, they successfully attached actin filaments between two optically trapped polystyrene particles (Figure 5). As a next step, bundling protein fascin will be introduced in the flow-chamber to bundle actin filaments attached to the two beads and unzipping forces required to unbundle these filaments will be measured.

The Finzi group (Emory Physics) routinely records transcription traces (Figure 6) to understand how RNA polymerase navigates roadblocks. They use Cy5-labelled DNA and Cy3-labelled RNAP and record kymographs that show the progress of elongating RNAP from E. coli along the template DNA. Such assays are at the basis of the Finzi group thrust to understand transcription through roadblocks. Preliminary results were used to apply for an NSF grant from MCB Genetic mechanisms.
